content: The Employee Rights Act, also known as the National Labor Relations Act, includes amendments to protect employee rights. The Employee Rights Act, or the National Labor Relations Act, is amended to address unfair labor practices and election procedures for collective bargaining. The amendments aim to prevent interference with employees' rights and ensure fair representation in secret ballot elections conducted by the Board. The Employee Rights Act is amended to address turnover, expansion, or alteration of bargaining units. The Board will conduct secret ballot elections among represented employees in certain circumstances to ensure fair representation. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to address turnover, expansion, or alteration of bargaining units. Secret ballot elections will be conducted among represented employees in certain circumstances to ensure fair representation. If a majority of votes reject the labor organization's representation, certification will be withdrawn, and any obligations in a collectively bargained contract will terminate. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to ensure fair representation in elections. Changes include inserting timeframes for hearings and providing a list of eligible voters to the Board within 7 days. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to ensure fair representation in elections by adding requirements for conducting hearings and resolving issues before election results are final and a labor organization is certified as the bargaining representative. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to require the Board to rule on pre-election issues and conduct a hearing before certifying a labor organization as the bargaining representative. Penalties are imposed on labor organizations that interfere with employees' rights under section 7 or with the filing of a decertification petition. Amendments to the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 include changes to the definition of voting methods, rights of employees in a bargaining unit, and the right not to subsidize nonrepresentational activities of labor organizations. Amendments to the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 include the right not to subsidize nonrepresentational activities of labor organizations. Amendments to the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 state that no employee's labor organization dues can be used for non-related purposes without written authorization. Additionally, no strike can begin without the consent of a majority of affected employees through a secret ballot vote. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 requires a secret ballot vote on any collective bargaining agreement offer before a strike can commence. Labor organizations must provide independently verified annual audit reports of their financial condition and operations, including information on represented unit nonmembers. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 is amended to prohibit acts of violence or threats to obtain rights or compensation related to employment. Violators may face fines or imprisonment. The Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1959 is amended to prohibit extortion by labor organizations or their agents, punishable by a fine up to $100,000 or imprisonment up to 10 years.
